# DNA

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For a non-technical introduction to the topic, see [Introduction to
genetics](/wiki/Introduction_to_genetics "Introduction to genetics"). For
other uses, see [DNA (disambiguation)](/wiki/DNA_\(disambiguation\) "DNA
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/DNA_Structure%2BKey%2BLabelled.pn_NoBB.png/340px-
DNA_Structure%2BKey%2BLabelled.pn_NoBB.png)](/wiki/File:DNA_Structure%2BKey%2BLabelled.pn_NoBB.png)

[](/wiki/File:DNA_Structure%2BKey%2BLabelled.pn_NoBB.png "Enlarge")

The structure of the DNA [double helix](/wiki/Double_helix "Double helix").
The [atoms](/wiki/Atom "Atom") in the structure are colour-coded by
[element](/wiki/Chemical_element "Chemical element") and the detailed
structures of two base pairs are shown in the bottom right.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/81/ADN_animation.gif)](/wiki/File:ADN_animation.gif)

[](/wiki/File:ADN_animation.gif "Enlarge")

The structure of part of a DNA [double helix](/wiki/Double_helix "Double
helix")

**Deoxyribonucleic acid** ([/diˈɒksiˌraɪboʊnjʊˈkliːɪk,
-ˈkleɪ.ɪk/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:En-us-Deoxyribonucleic_acid.ogg "About this
sound") [listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f2/En-us-
Deoxyribonucleic_acid.ogg "En-us-Deoxyribonucleic acid.ogg"));[1] **DNA**) is
a thread-like chain of [nucleotides](/wiki/Nucleotides "Nucleotides") carrying
the [genetic](/wiki/Genetics "Genetics") instructions used in the growth,
development, functioning and [reproduction](/wiki/Reproduction "Reproduction")
of all known living [organisms](/wiki/Organism "Organism") and many
[viruses](/wiki/Virus "Virus"). DNA and [ribonucleic
acid](/wiki/Ribonucleic_acid "Ribonucleic acid") (RNA) are [nucleic
acids](/wiki/Nucleic_acid "Nucleic acid"); alongside [proteins](/wiki/Protein
"Protein"), [lipids](/wiki/Lipids "Lipids") and complex carbohydrates
([polysaccharides](/wiki/Polysaccharide "Polysaccharide")), they are one of
the four major types of [macromolecules](/wiki/Macromolecule "Macromolecule")
that are essential for all known forms of [life](/wiki/Life "Life"). Most DNA
molecules consist of two [biopolymer](/wiki/Biopolymer "Biopolymer") strands
coiled around each other to form a [double
helix](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_double_helix "Nucleic acid double helix").

The two DNA strands are called [polynucleotides](/wiki/Polynucleotide
"Polynucleotide") since they are composed of simpler [monomer](/wiki/Monomer
"Monomer") units called [nucleotides](/wiki/Nucleotide "Nucleotide").[2][3]
Each nucleotide is composed of one of four [nitrogen-
containing](/wiki/Nitrogenous_base "Nitrogenous base")
[nucleobases](/wiki/Nucleobase "Nucleobase") ([cytosine](/wiki/Cytosine
"Cytosine") [C], [guanine](/wiki/Guanine "Guanine") [G],
[adenine](/wiki/Adenine "Adenine") [A] or [thymine](/wiki/Thymine "Thymine")
[T]), a [sugar](/wiki/Monosaccharide "Monosaccharide") called
[deoxyribose](/wiki/Deoxyribose "Deoxyribose"), and a [phosphate
group](/wiki/Organophosphate "Organophosphate"). The nucleotides are joined to
one another in a chain by [covalent bonds](/wiki/Covalent_bond "Covalent
bond") between the sugar of one nucleotide and the phosphate of the next,
resulting in an alternating [sugar-phosphate backbone](/wiki/Backbone_chain
"Backbone chain"). The nitrogenous bases of the two separate polynucleotide
strands are bound together, according to [base pairing](/wiki/Base_pair "Base
pair") rules (A with T and C with G), with [hydrogen
bonds](/wiki/Hydrogen_bond "Hydrogen bond") to make double-stranded DNA.

The complementary nitrogenous bases are divided into two groups, pyrimidines
and purines. In a DNA molecule, the pyrimidines are thymine and cytosine, the
purines are adenine and guanine.

DNA stores biological [information](/wiki/Information "Information"). The DNA
[backbone](/wiki/Backbone_chain "Backbone chain") is resistant to
[cleavage](/wiki/Bond_cleavage "Bond cleavage"), and both strands of the
double-stranded structure store the same biological information. This
information is replicated as and when the two strands separate. A large part
of DNA (more than 98% for humans) is [non-coding](/wiki/Non-coding_DNA "Non-
coding DNA"), meaning that these sections do not serve as patterns for protein
sequences.

The two strands of DNA run in opposite directions to each other and are thus
[antiparallel](/wiki/Antiparallel_\(biochemistry\) "Antiparallel
\(biochemistry\)"). Attached to each sugar is one of four types of nucleobases
(informally, _bases_). It is the [sequence](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_sequence
"Nucleic acid sequence") of these four nucleobases along the backbone that
encodes biological information. [RNA](/wiki/RNA "RNA") strands are created
using DNA strands as a template in a process called
[transcription](/wiki/Transcription_\(genetics\) "Transcription
\(genetics\)"). Under the [genetic code](/wiki/Genetic_code "Genetic code"),
these [RNA](/wiki/RNA "RNA") strands are translated to specify the sequence of
[amino acids](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid") within proteins in a process
called [translation](/wiki/Translation_\(genetics\) "Translation
\(genetics\)").

Within eukaryotic cells, DNA is organized into long structures called
[chromosomes](/wiki/Chromosome "Chromosome"). During [cell
division](/wiki/Cell_division "Cell division") these chromosomes are
duplicated in the process of [DNA replication](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA
replication"), providing each cell its own complete set of chromosomes.
[Eukaryotic organisms](/wiki/Eukaryote "Eukaryote") ([animals](/wiki/Animal
"Animal"), [plants](/wiki/Plant "Plant"), [fungi](/wiki/Fungus "Fungus") and
[protists](/wiki/Protist "Protist")) store most of their DNA inside the [cell
nucleus](/wiki/Cell_nucleus "Cell nucleus") and some of their DNA in
[organelles](/wiki/Organelle "Organelle"), such as
[mitochondria](/wiki/Mitochondrion "Mitochondrion") or
[chloroplasts](/wiki/Chloroplast "Chloroplast").[4] In contrast
[prokaryotes](/wiki/Prokaryote "Prokaryote") ([bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria
"Bacteria") and [archaea](/wiki/Archaea "Archaea")) store their DNA only in
the [cytoplasm](/wiki/Cytoplasm "Cytoplasm"). Within the eukaryotic
chromosomes, [chromatin](/wiki/Chromatin "Chromatin") proteins such as
[histones](/wiki/Histone "Histone") compact and organize DNA. These compact
structures guide the interactions between DNA and other proteins, helping
control which parts of the DNA are transcribed.

DNA was first isolated by [Friedrich Miescher](/wiki/Friedrich_Miescher
"Friedrich Miescher") in 1869. Its molecular structure was first identified by
[James Watson](/wiki/James_Watson "James Watson") and [Francis
Crick](/wiki/Francis_Crick "Francis Crick") at the [Cavendish
Laboratory](/wiki/Cavendish_Laboratory "Cavendish Laboratory") within the
[University of Cambridge](/wiki/University_of_Cambridge "University of
Cambridge") in 1953, whose model-building efforts were guided by [X-ray
diffraction](/wiki/X-ray_diffraction "X-ray diffraction") data acquired by
[Raymond Gosling](/wiki/Raymond_Gosling "Raymond Gosling"), who was a post-
graduate student of [Rosalind Franklin](/wiki/Rosalind_Franklin "Rosalind
Franklin"). DNA is used by researchers as a molecular tool to explore physical
laws and theories, such as the [ergodic theorem](/wiki/Ergodic_theorem
"Ergodic theorem") and the theory of [elasticity](/wiki/Elasticity_\(physics\)
"Elasticity \(physics\)"). The unique material properties of DNA have made it
an attractive molecule for material scientists and engineers interested in
micro- and nano-fabrication. Among notable advances in this field are [DNA
origami](/wiki/DNA_origami "DNA origami") and DNA-based hybrid materials.[5]

## Properties

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/DNA_chemical_structure.svg/300px-
DNA_chemical_structure.svg.png)](/wiki/File:DNA_chemical_structure.svg)

[](/wiki/File:DNA_chemical_structure.svg "Enlarge")

Chemical structure of DNA; [hydrogen bonds](/wiki/Hydrogen_bond "Hydrogen
bond") shown as dotted lines

DNA is a long [polymer](/wiki/Polymer "Polymer") made from repeating units
called [nucleotides](/wiki/Nucleotide "Nucleotide").[6][7] The structure of
DNA is dynamic along its length, being capable of coiling into tight loops,
and other shapes.[8] In all species it is composed of two helical chains,
bound to each other by [hydrogen bonds](/wiki/Hydrogen_bonds "Hydrogen
bonds"). Both chains are coiled round the same axis, and have the same pitch
of 34 [ångströms](/wiki/%C3%85ngstr%C3%B6m "Ångström") (3.4
[nanometres](/wiki/Nanometre "Nanometre")). The pair of chains has a radius of
10 ångströms (1.0 nanometre).[9] According to another study, when measured in
a different solution, the DNA chain measured 22 to 26 ångströms wide (2.2 to
2.6 nanometres), and one nucleotide unit measured 3.3 Å (0.33 nm) long.[10]
Although each individual nucleotide repeating unit is very small, DNA polymers
can be very large molecules containing millions to hundreds of millions of
nucleotides. For instance, the DNA in the largest human
[chromosome](/wiki/Chromosome "Chromosome"), chromosome [number
1](/wiki/Chromosome_1_\(human\) "Chromosome 1 \(human\)"), consists of
approximately 220 million [base pairs](/wiki/Base_pair "Base pair")[11] and
would be 85 mm long if straightened.

In living organisms, DNA does not usually exist as a single molecule, but
instead as a pair of molecules that are held tightly together.[12][13] These
two long strands entwine like vines, in the shape of a [double
helix](/wiki/Double_helix "Double helix"). The nucleotide contains both a
segment of the backbone of the molecule (which holds the chain together) and a
nucleobase (which interacts with the other DNA strand in the helix). A
nucleobase linked to a sugar is called a [nucleoside](/wiki/Nucleoside
"Nucleoside") and a base linked to a sugar and one or more phosphate groups is
called a [nucleotide](/wiki/Nucleotide "Nucleotide"). A polymer comprising
multiple linked nucleotides (as in DNA) is called a
[polynucleotide](/wiki/Polynucleotide "Polynucleotide").[14]

The backbone of the DNA strand is made from alternating
[phosphate](/wiki/Phosphate "Phosphate") and [sugar](/wiki/Carbohydrate
"Carbohydrate") residues.[15] The sugar in DNA is
2-[deoxyribose](/wiki/Deoxyribose "Deoxyribose"), which is a
[pentose](/wiki/Pentose "Pentose") (five-[carbon](/wiki/Carbon "Carbon"))
sugar. The sugars are joined together by phosphate groups that form
[phosphodiester bonds](/wiki/Phosphodiester_bond "Phosphodiester bond")
between the third and fifth carbon [atoms](/wiki/Atom "Atom") of adjacent
sugar rings. These asymmetric [bonds](/wiki/Covalent_bond "Covalent bond")
mean a strand of DNA has a direction. In a double helix, the direction of the
nucleotides in one strand is opposite to their direction in the other strand:
the strands are _antiparallel_. The asymmetric ends of DNA strands are said to
have a [directionality](/wiki/Directionality_\(molecular_biology\)
"Directionality \(molecular biology\)") of _five prime_ (5′) and _three prime_
(3′), with the 5′ end having a terminal phosphate group and the 3′ end a
terminal hydroxyl group. One major difference between DNA and [RNA](/wiki/RNA
"RNA") is the sugar, with the 2-deoxyribose in DNA being replaced by the
alternative pentose sugar [ribose](/wiki/Ribose "Ribose") in RNA.[13]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/DNA_orbit_animated_static_thumb.png/170px-
DNA_orbit_animated_static_thumb.png)](/wiki/File:DNA_orbit_animated_static_thumb.png)

[](/wiki/File:DNA_orbit_animated_static_thumb.png "Enlarge")

A section of DNA. The bases lie horizontally between the two spiraling
strands[16] ([animated version](/wiki/File:DNA_orbit_animated.gif "File:DNA
orbit animated.gif")).

The DNA double helix is stabilized primarily by two forces: [hydrogen
bonds](/wiki/Hydrogen_bond "Hydrogen bond") between nucleotides and [base-
stacking](/wiki/Stacking_\(chemistry\) "Stacking \(chemistry\)") interactions
among [aromatic](/wiki/Aromatic "Aromatic") nucleobases.[17] In the aqueous
environment of the cell, the conjugated [π bonds](/wiki/Pi_bond "Pi bond") of
nucleotide bases align perpendicular to the axis of the DNA molecule,
minimizing their interaction with the [solvation shell](/wiki/Solvation_shell
"Solvation shell"). The four bases found in DNA are [adenine](/wiki/Adenine
"Adenine") (A), [cytosine](/wiki/Cytosine "Cytosine") (C),
[guanine](/wiki/Guanine "Guanine") (G) and [thymine](/wiki/Thymine "Thymine")
(T). These four bases are attached to the sugar-phosphate to form the complete
nucleotide, as shown for [adenosine
monophosphate](/wiki/Adenosine_monophosphate "Adenosine monophosphate").
[Adenine](/wiki/Adenine "Adenine") pairs with [thymine](/wiki/Thymine
"Thymine") and [guanine](/wiki/Guanine "Guanine") pairs with
[cytosine](/wiki/Cytosine "Cytosine"). It was represented by A-T base pairs
and G-C base pairs.[18][19]

### Nucleobase classification

The nucleobases are classified into two types: the [purines](/wiki/Purine
"Purine"), A and G, being fused five- and six-membered [heterocyclic
compounds](/wiki/Heterocyclic_compound "Heterocyclic compound"), and the
[pyrimidines](/wiki/Pyrimidine "Pyrimidine"), the six-membered rings C and
T.[13] A fifth pyrimidine nucleobase, [uracil](/wiki/Uracil "Uracil") (U),
usually takes the place of thymine in RNA and differs from thymine by lacking
a [methyl group](/wiki/Methyl_group "Methyl group") on its ring. In addition
to RNA and DNA, many artificial [nucleic acid
analogues](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_analogue "Nucleic acid analogue") have been
created to study the properties of nucleic acids, or for use in
biotechnology.[20]

### Non canonical bases

Uracil is not usually found in DNA, occurring only as a breakdown product of
cytosine. However, in several bacteriophages, _Bacillus subtilis_
bacteriophages PBS1 and PBS2 and _Yersinia_ bacteriophage piR1-37, thymine has
been replaced by uracil.[21] Another phage - Staphylococcal phage S6 - has
been identified with a genome where thymine has been replaced by uracil.[22]

5-hydroxymethyldeoxyuridine,(hm5dU) is also known to replace thymidine in
several genomes including the _Bacillus_ phages SPO1, ϕe, SP8, H1, 2C and
SP82. Another modified uracil - 5-dihydroxypentauracil – has also been
described.[23]

[Base J](/wiki/Base_J "Base J") (beta-d-glucopyranosyloxymethyluracil), a
modified form of uracil, is also found in several organisms: the
[flagellates](/wiki/Flagellate "Flagellate")
_[Diplonema](/wiki/Diplonema_\(Excavata\) "Diplonema \(Excavata\)")_ and
_[Euglena](/wiki/Euglena "Euglena")_ , and all the
[kinetoplastid](/wiki/Kinetoplastida "Kinetoplastida") genera.[24]
[Biosynthesis](/wiki/Biosynthesis "Biosynthesis") of J occurs in two steps: in
the first step, a specific thymidine in DNA is converted into
hydroxymethyldeoxyuridine; in the second, HOMedU is
[glycosylated](/wiki/Glycosylation "Glycosylation") to form J.[25] Proteins
that bind specifically to this base have been identified.[26][27][28] These
proteins appear to be distant relatives of the Tet1 oncogene that is involved
in the pathogenesis of [acute myeloid leukemia](/wiki/Acute_myeloid_leukemia
"Acute myeloid leukemia").[29] J appears to act as a termination signal for
[RNA polymerase II](/wiki/RNA_polymerase_II "RNA polymerase II").[30][31]

In 1976 a [bacteriophage](/wiki/Bacteriophage "Bacteriophage") \- S-2L - which
infects species of the genus _[Synechocystis](/wiki/Synechocystis
"Synechocystis")_ was found to have all the adenosine bases within its genome
replaced by [2,6-diaminopurine](/wiki/Diaminopurine "Diaminopurine").[32] In
2016 deoxyarchaeosine was found to be present in the genomes of several
bacteria and the _[Escherichia](/wiki/Escherichia "Escherichia")_ phage
9g.[33]

Modified bases also occur in DNA. The first of these recognised was
[5-methylcytosine](/wiki/Methylcytosine "Methylcytosine") which was found in
the [genome](/wiki/Genome "Genome") of _[Mycobacterium
tuberculosis](/wiki/Mycobacterium_tuberculosis "Mycobacterium tuberculosis")_
in 1925.[34] The complete replacement of cytosine by
5-glycosylhydroxymethylcytosine in T even phages (T2, T4 and T6) was observed
in 1953[35] In the genomes of [Xanthomonas oryzae](/wiki/Xanthomonas_oryzae
"Xanthomonas oryzae") bacteriophage Xp12 and halovirus FH the full complement
of [cystosine](/wiki/Cytosine "Cytosine") has been replaced by
5-methylcytosine.[36][37] 6N-methyadenine was discovered to be present in DNA
in 1955.[38] N6-carbamoyl-methyladenine was described in 1975.[39]
7-[methylguanine](/wiki/Methylguanine "Methylguanine") was described in
1976.[40] [N4-methylcytosine](/wiki/N4-methylcytosine "N4-methylcytosine") in
DNA was described in 1983.[41] In 1985
[5-hydroxycytosine](/wiki/5-Hydroxycytosine "5-Hydroxycytosine") was found in
the genomes of the [Rhizobium](/wiki/Rhizobium "Rhizobium") phages RL38JI and
N17.[42] α-putrescinylthymine occurs in both the genomes of the _Delftia_
phage ΦW-14 and the _Bacillus_ phage SP10.[43] α-glutamylthymidine is found in
the Bacillus phage SP01 and 5-dihydroxypentyluracil is found in the Bacillus
phage SP15.

The reason for the presence of these non canonical bases in DNA is not known.
It seems likely that at least part of the reason for their presence in
bacterial viruses (phages) is to avoid the [restriction
enzymes](/wiki/Restriction_enzyme "Restriction enzyme") present in bacteria.
This enzyme system acts at least in part as a molecular immune system
protecting bacteria from infection by viruses.

This does not appear to be the entire story. Four modifications to the
cytosine residues in human DNA have been reported.[44] These modifications are
the addition of methyl (CH3)-, hydroxymethyl (CH2OH)-, formyl (CHO)- and
carboxyl (COOH)- groups. These modifications are thought to have regulatory
functions.

Uracil is found in the centromeric regions of at least two human chromosomes
(6 and 11).[45]

### Listing of non canonical bases found in DNA

Seventeen non canonical bases are known to occur in DNA. Most of these are
modifications of the canonical bases plus uracil.

  * Modified **Adenosine**
    * N6-carbamoyl-methyladenine
    * N6-methyadenine
  * Modified **Guanine**
    * 7-Methylguanine
  * Modified **Cytosine**
    * N4-Methylcytosine
    * 5-Carboxylcytosine
    * 5-Formylcytosine
    * 5-Glycosylhydroxymethylcytosine
    * 5-Hydroxycytosine
    * 5-Methylcytosine
  * Modified **Thymidine**
    * α-Glutamythymidine
    * α-Putrescinylthymine
  * **Uracil** and modifications 
    * Base J
    * Uracil
    * 5-Dihydroxypentauracil
    * 5-Hydroxymethyldeoxyuracil
  * Others 
    * Deoxyarchaeosine
    * 2,6-Diaminopurine

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/DNA-ligand-by-
Abalone.png/220px-DNA-ligand-by-Abalone.png)](/wiki/File:DNA-ligand-by-
Abalone.png)

[](/wiki/File:DNA-ligand-by-Abalone.png "Enlarge")

DNA major and minor grooves. The latter is a binding site for the [Hoechst
stain](/wiki/Hoechst_stain "Hoechst stain") dye 33258.

### Grooves

Twin helical strands form the DNA backbone. Another double helix may be found
tracing the spaces, or grooves, between the strands. These voids are adjacent
to the base pairs and may provide a [binding site](/wiki/Binding_site "Binding
site"). As the strands are not symmetrically located with respect to each
other, the grooves are unequally sized. One groove, the major groove, is 22
[Å](/wiki/%C3%85ngstr%C3%B6m "Ångström") wide and the other, the minor groove,
is 12 Å wide.[46] The width of the major groove means that the edges of the
bases are more accessible in the major groove than in the minor groove. As a
result, proteins such as [transcription factors](/wiki/Transcription_factor
"Transcription factor") that can bind to specific sequences in double-stranded
DNA usually make contact with the sides of the bases exposed in the major
groove.[47] This situation varies in unusual conformations of DNA within the
cell _(see below)_ , but the major and minor grooves are always named to
reflect the differences in size that would be seen if the DNA is twisted back
into the ordinary B form.

### Base pairing

Further information: [Base pair](/wiki/Base_pair "Base pair")

In a DNA double helix, each type of nucleobase on one strand bonds with just
one type of nucleobase on the other strand. This is called complementary [base
pairing](/wiki/Base_pair "Base pair"). Here, purines form [hydrogen
bonds](/wiki/Hydrogen_bond "Hydrogen bond") to pyrimidines, with adenine
bonding only to thymine in two hydrogen bonds, and cytosine bonding only to
guanine in three hydrogen bonds. This arrangement of two nucleotides binding
together across the double helix is called a Watson-Crick base pair. Another
type of base pairing is Hoogsteen base pairing where two hydrogen bonds form
between guanine and cytosine.[48] As hydrogen bonds are not
[covalent](/wiki/Covalent_bond "Covalent bond"), they can be broken and
rejoined relatively easily. The two strands of DNA in a double helix can thus
be pulled apart like a zipper, either by a mechanical force or high
[temperature](/wiki/Temperature "Temperature").[49] As a result of this base
pair complementarity, all the information in the double-stranded sequence of a
DNA helix is duplicated on each strand, which is vital in DNA replication.
This reversible and specific interaction between complementary base pairs is
critical for all the functions of DNA in living organisms.[7]

[![Base pair
GC.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Base_pair_GC.svg/282px-
Base_pair_GC.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Base_pair_GC.svg)  
---  
[![Base pair
AT.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Base_pair_AT.svg/282px-
Base_pair_AT.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Base_pair_AT.svg)  
---  
  
Top, a **GC** base pair with three [hydrogen bonds](/wiki/Hydrogen_bond
"Hydrogen bond"). Bottom, an **AT** base pair with two hydrogen bonds. Non-
covalent hydrogen bonds between the pairs are shown as dashed lines.

The two types of base pairs form different numbers of hydrogen bonds, AT
forming two hydrogen bonds, and GC forming three hydrogen bonds (see figures,
right). DNA with high [GC-content](/wiki/GC-content "GC-content") is more
stable than DNA with low GC-content.

As noted above, most DNA molecules are actually two polymer strands, bound
together in a helical fashion by noncovalent bonds; this double-stranded
(**dsDNA**) structure is maintained largely by the intrastrand base stacking
interactions, which are strongest for G,C stacks. The two strands can come
apart – a process known as melting – to form two single-stranded DNA
(**ssDNA**) molecules. Melting occurs at high temperature, low salt and high
[pH](/wiki/PH "PH") (low pH also melts DNA, but since DNA is unstable due to
acid depurination, low pH is rarely used).

The stability of the dsDNA form depends not only on the GC-content (% G,C
basepairs) but also on sequence (since stacking is sequence specific) and also
length (longer molecules are more stable). The stability can be measured in
various ways; a common way is the "melting temperature", which is the
temperature at which 50% of the ds molecules are converted to ss molecules;
melting temperature is dependent on ionic strength and the concentration of
DNA. As a result, it is both the percentage of GC base pairs and the overall
length of a DNA double helix that determines the strength of the association
between the two strands of DNA. Long DNA helices with a high GC-content have
stronger-interacting strands, while short helices with high AT content have
weaker-interacting strands.[50] In biology, parts of the DNA double helix that
need to separate easily, such as the TATAAT [Pribnow box](/wiki/Pribnow_box
"Pribnow box") in some [promoters](/wiki/Promoter_\(biology\) "Promoter
\(biology\)"), tend to have a high AT content, making the strands easier to
pull apart.[51]

In the laboratory, the strength of this interaction can be measured by finding
the temperature necessary to break the hydrogen bonds, their [melting
temperature](/wiki/DNA_melting "DNA melting") (also called _T m_ value). When
all the base pairs in a DNA double helix melt, the strands separate and exist
in solution as two entirely independent molecules. These single-stranded DNA
molecules have no single common shape, but some conformations are more stable
than others.[52]

### Sense and antisense

Further information: [Sense (molecular
biology)](/wiki/Sense_\(molecular_biology\) "Sense \(molecular biology\)")

A DNA sequence is called "sense" if its sequence is the same as that of a
[messenger RNA](/wiki/Messenger_RNA "Messenger RNA") copy that is translated
into protein.[53] The sequence on the opposite strand is called the
"antisense" sequence. Both sense and antisense sequences can exist on
different parts of the same strand of DNA (i.e. both strands can contain both
sense and antisense sequences). In both prokaryotes and eukaryotes, antisense
RNA sequences are produced, but the functions of these RNAs are not entirely
clear.[54] One proposal is that antisense RNAs are involved in regulating
[gene expression](/wiki/Gene_expression "Gene expression") through RNA-RNA
base pairing.[55]

A few DNA sequences in prokaryotes and eukaryotes, and more in
[plasmids](/wiki/Plasmid "Plasmid") and [viruses](/wiki/Virus "Virus"), blur
the distinction between sense and antisense strands by having [overlapping
genes](/wiki/Overlapping_gene "Overlapping gene").[56] In these cases, some
DNA sequences do double duty, encoding one protein when read along one strand,
and a second protein when read in the opposite direction along the other
strand. In [bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria "Bacteria"), this overlap may be involved
in the regulation of gene transcription,[57] while in viruses, overlapping
genes increase the amount of information that can be encoded within the small
viral genome.[58]

### Supercoiling

Further information: [DNA supercoil](/wiki/DNA_supercoil "DNA supercoil")

DNA can be twisted like a rope in a process called [DNA
supercoiling](/wiki/DNA_supercoil "DNA supercoil"). With DNA in its "relaxed"
state, a strand usually circles the axis of the double helix once every 10.4
base pairs, but if the DNA is twisted the strands become more tightly or more
loosely wound.[59] If the DNA is twisted in the direction of the helix, this
is positive supercoiling, and the bases are held more tightly together. If
they are twisted in the opposite direction, this is negative supercoiling, and
the bases come apart more easily. In nature, most DNA has slight negative
supercoiling that is introduced by [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") called
[topoisomerases](/wiki/Topoisomerase "Topoisomerase").[60] These enzymes are
also needed to relieve the twisting stresses introduced into DNA strands
during processes such as [transcription](/wiki/Transcription_\(genetics\)
"Transcription \(genetics\)") and [DNA replication](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA
replication").[61]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/A-DNA%2C_B-DNA_and_Z-
DNA.png/220px-A-DNA%2C_B-DNA_and_Z-DNA.png)](/wiki/File:A-DNA,_B-DNA_and_Z-
DNA.png)

[](/wiki/File:A-DNA,_B-DNA_and_Z-DNA.png "Enlarge")

From left to right, the structures of A, B and Z DNA

### Alternative DNA structures

Further information: [Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for
Deoxyribose Nucleic
Acid](/wiki/Molecular_Structure_of_Nucleic_Acids:_A_Structure_for_Deoxyribose_Nucleic_Acid
"Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic
Acid"), [Molecular models of DNA](/wiki/Molecular_models_of_DNA "Molecular
models of DNA"), and [DNA structure](/wiki/DNA_structure "DNA structure")

DNA exists in many possible [conformations](/wiki/Conformational_isomerism
"Conformational isomerism") that include [A-DNA](/wiki/A-DNA "A-DNA"), B-DNA,
and [Z-DNA](/wiki/Z-DNA "Z-DNA") forms, although, only B-DNA and Z-DNA have
been directly observed in functional organisms.[15] The conformation that DNA
adopts depends on the hydration level, DNA sequence, the amount and direction
of supercoiling, chemical modifications of the bases, the type and
concentration of metal [ions](/wiki/Ion "Ion"), and the presence of
[polyamines](/wiki/Polyamine "Polyamine") in solution.[62]

The first published reports of A-DNA [X-ray diffraction
patterns](/wiki/X-ray_scattering_techniques "X-ray scattering techniques")—and
also B-DNA—used analyses based on [Patterson
transforms](/wiki/Patterson_function "Patterson function") that provided only
a limited amount of structural information for oriented fibers of DNA.[63][64]
An alternative analysis was then proposed by Wilkins _et al._ , in 1953, for
the _[in vivo](/wiki/In_vivo "In vivo")_ B-DNA X-ray diffraction-scattering
patterns of highly hydrated DNA fibers in terms of squares of [Bessel
functions](/wiki/Bessel_function "Bessel function").[65] In the same journal,
[James Watson](/wiki/James_Watson "James Watson") and [Francis
Crick](/wiki/Francis_Crick "Francis Crick") presented their [molecular
modeling](/wiki/Molecular_models_of_DNA "Molecular models of DNA") analysis of
the DNA X-ray diffraction patterns to suggest that the structure was a double-
helix.[9]

Although the _B-DNA form_ is most common under the conditions found in
cells,[66] it is not a well-defined conformation but a family of related DNA
conformations[67] that occur at the high hydration levels present in living
cells. Their corresponding X-ray diffraction and scattering patterns are
characteristic of molecular [paracrystals](/wiki/Paracrystalline
"Paracrystalline") with a significant degree of disorder.[68][69]

Compared to B-DNA, the A-DNA form is a wider [right-handed](/wiki/Helix#Types
"Helix") spiral, with a shallow, wide minor groove and a narrower, deeper
major groove. The A form occurs under non-physiological conditions in partly
dehydrated samples of DNA, while in the cell it may be produced in hybrid
pairings of DNA and RNA strands, and in enzyme-DNA complexes.[70][71] Segments
of DNA where the bases have been chemically modified by
[methylation](/wiki/Methylation "Methylation") may undergo a larger change in
conformation and adopt the [Z form](/wiki/Z-DNA "Z-DNA"). Here, the strands
turn about the helical axis in a left-handed spiral, the opposite of the more
common B form.[72] These unusual structures can be recognized by specific
Z-DNA binding proteins and may be involved in the regulation of
transcription.[73]

### Alternative DNA chemistry

For many years [exobiologists](/wiki/Astrobiology "Astrobiology") have
proposed the existence of a [shadow biosphere](/wiki/Shadow_biosphere "Shadow
biosphere"), a postulated microbial biosphere of Earth that uses radically
different biochemical and molecular processes than currently known life. One
of the proposals was the existence of lifeforms that use [arsenic instead of
phosphorus in DNA](/wiki/Arsenic_DNA "Arsenic DNA"). A report in 2010 of the
possibility in the [bacterium](/wiki/Bacterium "Bacterium")
[GFAJ-1](/wiki/GFAJ-1 "GFAJ-1"), was announced,[74][74][75] though the
research was disputed,[75][76] and evidence suggests the bacterium actively
prevents the incorporation of arsenic into the DNA backbone and other
biomolecules.[77]

### Quadruplex structures

Further information: [G-quadruplex](/wiki/G-quadruplex "G-quadruplex")

At the ends of the linear chromosomes are specialized regions of DNA called
[telomeres](/wiki/Telomere "Telomere"). The main function of these regions is
to allow the cell to replicate chromosome ends using the enzyme
[telomerase](/wiki/Telomerase "Telomerase"), as the enzymes that normally
replicate DNA cannot copy the extreme 3′ ends of chromosomes.[78] These
specialized chromosome caps also help protect the DNA ends, and stop the [DNA
repair](/wiki/DNA_repair "DNA repair") systems in the cell from treating them
as damage to be corrected.[79] In [human
cells](/wiki/List_of_distinct_cell_types_in_the_adult_human_body "List of
distinct cell types in the adult human body"), telomeres are usually lengths
of single-stranded DNA containing several thousand repeats of a simple TTAGGG
sequence.[80]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Parallel_telomere_quadruple.png/220px-
Parallel_telomere_quadruple.png)](/wiki/File:Parallel_telomere_quadruple.png)

[](/wiki/File:Parallel_telomere_quadruple.png "Enlarge")

DNA quadruplex formed by [telomere](/wiki/Telomere "Telomere") repeats. The
looped conformation of the DNA backbone is very different from the typical DNA
helix. The green spheres in the center represent potassium ions.[81]

These guanine-rich sequences may stabilize chromosome ends by forming
structures of stacked sets of four-base units, rather than the usual base
pairs found in other DNA molecules. Here, four guanine bases form a flat plate
and these flat four-base units then stack on top of each other, to form a
stable [G-quadruplex](/wiki/G-quadruplex "G-quadruplex") structure.[82] These
structures are stabilized by hydrogen bonding between the edges of the bases
and [chelation](/wiki/Chelation "Chelation") of a metal ion in the centre of
each four-base unit.[83] Other structures can also be formed, with the central
set of four bases coming from either a single strand folded around the bases,
or several different parallel strands, each contributing one base to the
central structure.

In addition to these stacked structures, telomeres also form large loop
structures called telomere loops, or T-loops. Here, the single-stranded DNA
curls around in a long circle stabilized by telomere-binding proteins.[84] At
the very end of the T-loop, the single-stranded telomere DNA is held onto a
region of double-stranded DNA by the telomere strand disrupting the double-
helical DNA and base pairing to one of the two strands. This [triple-
stranded](/wiki/Triple-stranded_DNA "Triple-stranded DNA") structure is called
a displacement loop or [D-loop](/wiki/D-loop "D-loop").[82]

[![Branch-dna-single.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Branch-dna-single.svg/95px-Branch-dna-single.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Branch-dna-single.svg) | [![Branch-DNA-multiple.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Branch-DNA-multiple.svg/95px-Branch-DNA-multiple.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Branch-DNA-multiple.svg)  
---|---  
Single branch | Multiple branches  
  
[Branched DNA](/wiki/Branched_DNA "Branched DNA") can form networks containing
multiple branches.

### Branched DNA

Further information: [Branched DNA](/wiki/Branched_DNA "Branched DNA") and
[DNA nanotechnology](/wiki/DNA_nanotechnology "DNA nanotechnology")

In DNA, [fraying](/wiki/DNA_end#Frayed_ends "DNA end") occurs when non-
complementary regions exist at the end of an otherwise complementary double-
strand of DNA. However, branched DNA can occur if a third strand of DNA is
introduced and contains adjoining regions able to hybridize with the frayed
regions of the pre-existing double-strand. Although the simplest example of
branched DNA involves only three strands of DNA, complexes involving
additional strands and multiple branches are also possible.[85] Branched DNA
can be used in [nanotechnology](/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology") to
construct geometric shapes, see the section on [uses in
technology](/wiki/DNA#Uses_in_technology "DNA") below.

## Chemical modifications and altered DNA packaging

---|---|---  
[cytosine](/wiki/Cytosine "Cytosine") | [5-methylcytosine](/wiki/5-Methylcytosine "5-Methylcytosine") | [thymine](/wiki/Thymine "Thymine")
