[Deamination](/wiki/Deamination "Deamination") converts 5-methylcytosine into
thymine.

### Base modifications and DNA packaging

Further information: [DNA methylation](/wiki/DNA_methylation "DNA
methylation") and [Chromatin remodeling](/wiki/Chromatin_remodeling "Chromatin
remodeling")

The expression of genes is influenced by how the DNA is packaged in
chromosomes, in a structure called [chromatin](/wiki/Chromatin "Chromatin").
Base modifications can be involved in packaging, with regions that have low or
no gene expression usually containing high levels of
[methylation](/wiki/Methylation "Methylation") of [cytosine](/wiki/Cytosine
"Cytosine") bases. DNA packaging and its influence on gene expression can also
occur by covalent modifications of the [histone](/wiki/Histone "Histone")
protein core around which DNA is wrapped in the chromatin structure or else by
remodeling carried out by chromatin remodeling complexes (see [Chromatin
remodeling](/wiki/Chromatin_remodeling "Chromatin remodeling")). There is,
further, [crosstalk](/wiki/Crosstalk_\(biology\) "Crosstalk \(biology\)")
between DNA methylation and histone modification, so they can coordinately
affect chromatin and gene expression.[86]

For one example, cytosine methylation produces
[5-methylcytosine](/wiki/5-Methylcytosine "5-Methylcytosine"), which is
important for [X-inactivation](/wiki/X-inactivation "X-inactivation") of
chromosomes.[87] The average level of methylation varies between organisms –
the worm _[Caenorhabditis elegans](/wiki/Caenorhabditis_elegans
"Caenorhabditis elegans")_ lacks cytosine methylation, while
[vertebrates](/wiki/Vertebrate "Vertebrate") have higher levels, with up to 1%
of their DNA containing 5-methylcytosine.[88] Despite the importance of
5-methylcytosine, it can [deaminate](/wiki/Deamination "Deamination") to leave
a thymine base, so methylated cytosines are particularly prone to
[mutations](/wiki/Mutation "Mutation").[89] Other base modifications include
adenine methylation in bacteria, the presence of
[5-hydroxymethylcytosine](/wiki/5-hydroxymethylcytosine
"5-hydroxymethylcytosine") in the [brain](/wiki/Brain "Brain"),[90] and the
[glycosylation](/wiki/Glycosylation "Glycosylation") of uracil to produce the
"J-base" in [kinetoplastids](/wiki/Kinetoplastida "Kinetoplastida").[91][92]

### Damage

Further information: [DNA damage (naturally
occurring)](/wiki/DNA_damage_\(naturally_occurring\) "DNA damage \(naturally
occurring\)"), [Mutation](/wiki/Mutation "Mutation"), and [DNA damage theory
of aging](/wiki/DNA_damage_theory_of_aging "DNA damage theory of aging")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Benzopyrene_DNA_adduct_1JDG.png/220px-
Benzopyrene_DNA_adduct_1JDG.png)](/wiki/File:Benzopyrene_DNA_adduct_1JDG.png)

[](/wiki/File:Benzopyrene_DNA_adduct_1JDG.png "Enlarge")

A [covalent](/wiki/Covalent "Covalent") [adduct](/wiki/Adduct "Adduct")
between a [metabolically activated](/wiki/Cytochrome_P450,_family_1,_member_A1
"Cytochrome P450, family 1, member A1") form of
[benzo[_a_]pyrene](/wiki/Benzo\(a\)pyrene "Benzo\(a\)pyrene"), the major
[mutagen](/wiki/Mutagen "Mutagen") in [tobacco smoke](/wiki/Tobacco_smoking
"Tobacco smoking"), and DNA[93]

DNA can be damaged by many sorts of [mutagens](/wiki/Mutagen "Mutagen"), which
change the DNA sequence. Mutagens include [oxidizing
agents](/wiki/Oxidizing_agent "Oxidizing agent"), [alkylating
agents](/wiki/Alkylation "Alkylation") and also high-energy [electromagnetic
radiation](/wiki/Electromagnetic_radiation "Electromagnetic radiation") such
as [ultraviolet](/wiki/Ultraviolet "Ultraviolet") light and
[X-rays](/wiki/X-ray "X-ray"). The type of DNA damage produced depends on the
type of mutagen. For example, UV light can damage DNA by producing [thymine
dimers](/wiki/Thymine_dimer "Thymine dimer"), which are cross-links between
pyrimidine bases.[94] On the other hand, oxidants such as [free
radicals](/wiki/Radical_\(chemistry\) "Radical \(chemistry\)") or [hydrogen
peroxide](/wiki/Hydrogen_peroxide "Hydrogen peroxide") produce multiple forms
of damage, including base modifications, particularly of guanosine, and
double-strand breaks.[95] A typical human cell contains about 150,000 bases
that have suffered oxidative damage.[96] Of these oxidative lesions, the most
dangerous are double-strand breaks, as these are difficult to repair and can
produce [point mutations](/wiki/Point_mutation "Point mutation"),
[insertions](/wiki/Genetic_insertion "Genetic insertion"),
[deletions](/wiki/Deletion_\(genetics\) "Deletion \(genetics\)") from the DNA
sequence, and [chromosomal translocations](/wiki/Chromosomal_translocation
"Chromosomal translocation").[97] These mutations can cause
[cancer](/wiki/Cancer "Cancer"). Because of inherent limits in the DNA repair
mechanisms, if humans lived long enough, they would all eventually develop
cancer.[98][99] DNA damages that are [naturally
occurring](/wiki/DNA_damage_\(naturally_occurring\) "DNA damage \(naturally
occurring\)"), due to normal cellular processes that produce reactive oxygen
species, the hydrolytic activities of cellular water, etc., also occur
frequently. Although most of these damages are repaired, in any cell some DNA
damage may remain despite the action of repair processes. These remaining DNA
damages accumulate with age in mammalian postmitotic tissues. This
accumulation appears to be an important underlying cause of
aging.[100][101][102]

Many mutagens fit into the space between two adjacent base pairs, this is
called _[intercalation](/wiki/Intercalation_\(biochemistry\) "Intercalation
\(biochemistry\)")_. Most intercalators are [aromatic](/wiki/Aromaticity
"Aromaticity") and planar molecules; examples include [ethidium
bromide](/wiki/Ethidium_bromide "Ethidium bromide"),
[acridines](/wiki/Acridine "Acridine"), [daunomycin](/wiki/Daunorubicin
"Daunorubicin"), and [doxorubicin](/wiki/Doxorubicin "Doxorubicin"). For an
intercalator to fit between base pairs, the bases must separate, distorting
the DNA strands by unwinding of the double helix. This inhibits both
transcription and DNA replication, causing toxicity and mutations.[103] As a
result, DNA intercalators may be [carcinogens](/wiki/Carcinogen "Carcinogen"),
and in the case of thalidomide, a [teratogen](/wiki/Teratogen
"Teratogen").[104] Others such as [benzo[_a_]pyrene diol
epoxide](/wiki/Benzo\(a\)pyrene "Benzo\(a\)pyrene") and
[aflatoxin](/wiki/Aflatoxin "Aflatoxin") form DNA adducts that induce errors
in replication.[105] Nevertheless, due to their ability to inhibit DNA
transcription and replication, other similar toxins are also used in
[chemotherapy](/wiki/Chemotherapy "Chemotherapy") to inhibit rapidly growing
[cancer](/wiki/Cancer "Cancer") cells.[106]

## Biological functions

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Eukaryote_DNA-
en.svg/320px-Eukaryote_DNA-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Eukaryote_DNA-en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Eukaryote_DNA-en.svg "Enlarge")

Location of eukaryote [nuclear DNA](/wiki/Nuclear_DNA "Nuclear DNA") within
the chromosomes

DNA usually occurs as linear [chromosomes](/wiki/Chromosome "Chromosome") in
[eukaryotes](/wiki/Eukaryote "Eukaryote"), and circular chromosomes in
[prokaryotes](/wiki/Prokaryote "Prokaryote"). The set of chromosomes in a cell
makes up its [genome](/wiki/Genome "Genome"); the [human
genome](/wiki/Human_genome "Human genome") has approximately 3 billion base
pairs of DNA arranged into 46 chromosomes.[107] The information carried by DNA
is held in the [sequence](/wiki/DNA_sequence "DNA sequence") of pieces of DNA
called [genes](/wiki/Gene "Gene").
[Transmission](/wiki/Transmission_\(genetics\) "Transmission \(genetics\)") of
genetic information in genes is achieved via complementary base pairing. For
example, in transcription, when a cell uses the information in a gene, the DNA
sequence is copied into a complementary RNA sequence through the attraction
between the DNA and the correct RNA nucleotides. Usually, this RNA copy is
then used to make a matching [protein sequence](/wiki/Peptide_sequence
"Peptide sequence") in a process called
[translation](/wiki/Translation_\(biology\) "Translation \(biology\)"), which
depends on the same interaction between RNA nucleotides. In alternative
fashion, a cell may simply copy its genetic information in a process called
DNA replication. The details of these functions are covered in other articles;
here the focus is on the interactions between DNA and other molecules that
mediate the function of the genome.

### Genes and genomes

Further information: [Cell nucleus](/wiki/Cell_nucleus "Cell nucleus"),
[Chromatin](/wiki/Chromatin "Chromatin"), [Chromosome](/wiki/Chromosome
"Chromosome"), [Gene](/wiki/Gene "Gene"), and [Noncoding
DNA](/wiki/Noncoding_DNA "Noncoding DNA")

Genomic DNA is tightly and orderly packed in the process called [DNA
condensation](/wiki/DNA_condensation "DNA condensation"), to fit the small
available volumes of the cell. In eukaryotes, DNA is located in the [cell
nucleus](/wiki/Cell_nucleus "Cell nucleus"), with small amounts in
[mitochondria](/wiki/Mitochondrion "Mitochondrion") and
[chloroplasts](/wiki/Chloroplast "Chloroplast"). In prokaryotes, the DNA is
held within an irregularly shaped body in the cytoplasm called the
[nucleoid](/wiki/Nucleoid "Nucleoid").[108] The genetic information in a
genome is held within genes, and the complete set of this information in an
organism is called its [genotype](/wiki/Genotype "Genotype"). A gene is a unit
of [heredity](/wiki/Heredity "Heredity") and is a region of DNA that
influences a particular characteristic in an organism. Genes contain an [open
reading frame](/wiki/Open_reading_frame "Open reading frame") that can be
transcribed, and [regulatory sequences](/wiki/Regulatory_sequence "Regulatory
sequence") such as [promoters](/wiki/Promoter_\(biology\) "Promoter
\(biology\)") and [enhancers](/wiki/Enhancer_\(genetics\) "Enhancer
\(genetics\)"), which control transcription of the open reading frame.

In many [species](/wiki/Species "Species"), only a small fraction of the total
sequence of the [genome](/wiki/Genome "Genome") encodes protein. For example,
only about 1.5% of the human genome consists of protein-coding
[exons](/wiki/Exon "Exon"), with over 50% of human DNA consisting of non-
coding [repetitive sequences](/wiki/Repeated_sequence_\(DNA\) "Repeated
sequence \(DNA\)").[109] The reasons for the presence of so much [noncoding
DNA](/wiki/Noncoding_DNA "Noncoding DNA") in eukaryotic genomes and the
extraordinary differences in [genome size](/wiki/Genome_size "Genome size"),
or _[C-value](/wiki/C-value "C-value")_ , among species, represent a long-
standing puzzle known as the "[C-value enigma](/wiki/C-value_enigma "C-value
enigma")".[110] However, some DNA sequences that do not code protein may still
encode functional [non-coding RNA](/wiki/Non-coding_RNA "Non-coding RNA")
molecules, which are involved in the [regulation of gene
expression](/wiki/Regulation_of_gene_expression "Regulation of gene
expression").[111]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/T7_RNA_polymerase.jpg/220px-T7_RNA_polymerase.jpg)](/wiki/File:T7_RNA_polymerase.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:T7_RNA_polymerase.jpg "Enlarge")

[T7 RNA polymerase](/wiki/T7_RNA_polymerase "T7 RNA polymerase") (blue)
producing an mRNA (green) from a DNA template (orange)[112]

Some noncoding DNA sequences play structural roles in chromosomes.
[Telomeres](/wiki/Telomere "Telomere") and [centromeres](/wiki/Centromere
"Centromere") typically contain few genes but are important for the function
and stability of chromosomes.[79][113] An abundant form of noncoding DNA in
humans are [pseudogenes](/wiki/Pseudogene "Pseudogene"), which are copies of
genes that have been disabled by mutation.[114] These sequences are usually
just molecular [fossils](/wiki/Fossil "Fossil"), although they can
occasionally serve as raw [genetic material](/wiki/Genome "Genome") for the
creation of new genes through the process of [gene
duplication](/wiki/Gene_duplication "Gene duplication") and
[divergence](/wiki/Divergent_evolution "Divergent evolution").[115]

### Transcription and translation

Further information: [Genetic code](/wiki/Genetic_code "Genetic code"),
[Transcription (genetics)](/wiki/Transcription_\(genetics\) "Transcription
\(genetics\)"), and [Protein biosynthesis](/wiki/Protein_biosynthesis "Protein
biosynthesis")

A gene is a sequence of DNA that contains genetic information and can
influence the [phenotype](/wiki/Phenotype "Phenotype") of an organism. Within
a gene, the sequence of bases along a DNA strand defines a [messenger
RNA](/wiki/Messenger_RNA "Messenger RNA") sequence, which then defines one or
more protein sequences. The relationship between the nucleotide sequences of
genes and the [amino-acid](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid") sequences of
proteins is determined by the rules of
[translation](/wiki/Translation_\(biology\) "Translation \(biology\)"), known
collectively as the [genetic code](/wiki/Genetic_code "Genetic code"). The
genetic code consists of three-letter 'words' called _codons_ formed from a
sequence of three nucleotides (e.g. ACT, CAG, TTT).

In transcription, the codons of a gene are copied into messenger RNA by [RNA
polymerase](/wiki/RNA_polymerase "RNA polymerase"). This RNA copy is then
decoded by a [ribosome](/wiki/Ribosome "Ribosome") that reads the RNA sequence
by base-pairing the messenger RNA to [transfer RNA](/wiki/Transfer_RNA
"Transfer RNA"), which carries amino acids. Since there are 4 bases in
3-letter combinations, there are 64 possible codons (43 combinations). These
encode the twenty [standard amino acids](/wiki/List_of_standard_amino_acids
"List of standard amino acids"), giving most amino acids more than one
possible codon. There are also three 'stop' or 'nonsense' codons signifying
the end of the coding region; these are the TAA, TGA, and TAG codons.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/DNA_replication_en.svg/450px-
DNA_replication_en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:DNA_replication_en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:DNA_replication_en.svg "Enlarge")

DNA replication. The double helix is unwound by a [helicase](/wiki/Helicase
"Helicase") and [topoisomerase](/wiki/Topoisomerase "Topoisomerase"). Next,
one [DNA polymerase](/wiki/DNA_polymerase "DNA polymerase") produces the
[leading strand](/wiki/Replication_fork "Replication fork") copy. Another DNA
polymerase binds to the [lagging strand](/wiki/Replication_fork "Replication
fork"). This enzyme makes discontinuous segments (called [Okazaki
fragments](/wiki/Okazaki_fragment "Okazaki fragment")) before [DNA
ligase](/wiki/DNA_ligase "DNA ligase") joins them together.

### Replication

Further information: [DNA replication](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA
replication")

[Cell division](/wiki/Cell_division "Cell division") is essential for an
organism to grow, but, when a cell divides, it must replicate the DNA in its
genome so that the two daughter cells have the same genetic information as
their parent. The double-stranded structure of DNA provides a simple mechanism
for [DNA replication](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA replication"). Here, the two
strands are separated and then each strand's [complementary
DNA](/wiki/Complementary_DNA "Complementary DNA") sequence is recreated by an
[enzyme](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") called [DNA polymerase](/wiki/DNA_polymerase
"DNA polymerase"). This enzyme makes the complementary strand by finding the
correct base through complementary base pairing and bonding it onto the
original strand. As DNA polymerases can only extend a DNA strand in a 5′ to 3′
direction, different mechanisms are used to copy the antiparallel strands of
the double helix.[116] In this way, the base on the old strand dictates which
base appears on the new strand, and the cell ends up with a perfect copy of
its DNA.

### Extracellular nucleic acids

Naked extracellular DNA (eDNA), most of it released by cell death, is nearly
ubiquitous in the environment. Its concentration in soil may be as high as 2
μg/L, and its concentration in natural aquatic environments may be as high at
88 μg/L.[117] Various possible functions have been proposed for eDNA: it may
be involved in horizontal gene transfer;[118] it may provide nutrients;[119]
and it may act as a buffer to recruit or titrate ions or antibiotics.[120]
Extracellular DNA acts as a functional extracellular matrix component in the
[biofilms](/wiki/Biofilm "Biofilm") of several bacterial species. It may act
as a recognition factor to regulate the attachment and dispersal of specific
cell types in the biofilm;[121] it may contribute to biofilm formation;[122]
and it may contribute to the biofilm's physical strength and resistance to
biological stress.[123]

[Cell-free fetal DNA](/wiki/Cell-free_fetal_DNA "Cell-free fetal DNA") is
found in the blood of the mother, and can be sequenced to determine a great
deal of information about the developing fetus.[124]

## Interactions with proteins

All the functions of DNA depend on interactions with proteins. These [protein
interactions](/wiki/Protein_interactions "Protein interactions") can be non-
specific, or the protein can bind specifically to a single DNA sequence.
Enzymes can also bind to DNA and of these, the polymerases that copy the DNA
base sequence in transcription and DNA replication are particularly important.

### DNA-binding proteins

Further information: [DNA-binding protein](/wiki/DNA-binding_protein "DNA-
binding protein")

[![Nucleosome1.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Nucleosome1.png/260px-
Nucleosome1.png)](/wiki/File:Nucleosome1.png)  
---  
  
Interaction of DNA (in orange) with [histones](/wiki/Histone "Histone") (in
blue). These proteins' basic amino acids bind to the acidic phosphate groups
on DNA.

Structural proteins that bind DNA are well-understood examples of non-specific
DNA-protein interactions. Within chromosomes, DNA is held in complexes with
structural proteins. These proteins organize the DNA into a compact structure
called [chromatin](/wiki/Chromatin "Chromatin"). In eukaryotes, this structure
involves DNA binding to a complex of small basic proteins called
[histones](/wiki/Histone "Histone"), while in prokaryotes multiple types of
proteins are involved.[125][126] The histones form a disk-shaped complex
called a [nucleosome](/wiki/Nucleosome "Nucleosome"), which contains two
complete turns of double-stranded DNA wrapped around its surface. These non-
specific interactions are formed through basic residues in the histones,
making [ionic bonds](/wiki/Ionic_bond "Ionic bond") to the acidic sugar-
phosphate backbone of the DNA, and are thus largely independent of the base
sequence.[127] Chemical modifications of these basic amino acid residues
include [methylation](/wiki/Methylation "Methylation"),
[phosphorylation](/wiki/Phosphorylation "Phosphorylation"), and
[acetylation](/wiki/Acetylation "Acetylation").[128] These chemical changes
alter the strength of the interaction between the DNA and the histones, making
the DNA more or less accessible to [transcription
factors](/wiki/Transcription_factor "Transcription factor") and changing the
rate of transcription.[129] Other non-specific DNA-binding proteins in
chromatin include the high-mobility group proteins, which bind to bent or
distorted DNA.[130] These proteins are important in bending arrays of
nucleosomes and arranging them into the larger structures that make up
chromosomes.[131]

A distinct group of DNA-binding proteins is the DNA-binding proteins that
specifically bind single-stranded DNA. In humans, replication [protein
A](/wiki/Protein_A "Protein A") is the best-understood member of this family
and is used in processes where the double helix is separated, including DNA
replication, recombination, and DNA repair.[132] These binding proteins seem
to stabilize single-stranded DNA and protect it from forming [stem-
loops](/wiki/Stem-loop "Stem-loop") or being degraded by
[nucleases](/wiki/Nuclease "Nuclease").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Lambda_repressor_1LMB.png/170px-
Lambda_repressor_1LMB.png)](/wiki/File:Lambda_repressor_1LMB.png)

[](/wiki/File:Lambda_repressor_1LMB.png "Enlarge")

The lambda repressor [helix-turn-helix](/wiki/Helix-turn-helix "Helix-turn-
helix") transcription factor bound to its DNA target[133]

In contrast, other proteins have evolved to bind to particular DNA sequences.
The most intensively studied of these are the various [transcription
factors](/wiki/Transcription_factor "Transcription factor"), which are
proteins that regulate transcription. Each transcription factor binds to one
particular set of DNA sequences and activates or inhibits the transcription of
genes that have these sequences close to their promoters. The transcription
factors do this in two ways. Firstly, they can bind the RNA polymerase
responsible for transcription, either directly or through other mediator
proteins; this locates the polymerase at the promoter and allows it to begin
transcription.[134] Alternatively, transcription factors can bind
[enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") that modify the histones at the promoter.
This changes the accessibility of the DNA template to the polymerase.[135]

As these DNA targets can occur throughout an organism's genome, changes in the
activity of one type of transcription factor can affect thousands of
genes.[136] Consequently, these proteins are often the targets of the [signal
transduction](/wiki/Signal_transduction "Signal transduction") processes that
control responses to environmental changes or [cellular
differentiation](/wiki/Cellular_differentiation "Cellular differentiation")
and development. The specificity of these transcription factors' interactions
with DNA come from the proteins making multiple contacts to the edges of the
DNA bases, allowing them to "read" the DNA sequence. Most of these base-
interactions are made in the major groove, where the bases are most
accessible.[47]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/EcoRV_1RVA.png/220px-
EcoRV_1RVA.png)](/wiki/File:EcoRV_1RVA.png)

[](/wiki/File:EcoRV_1RVA.png "Enlarge")

The [restriction enzyme](/wiki/Restriction_enzyme "Restriction enzyme")
[EcoRV](/wiki/EcoRV "EcoRV") (green) in a complex with its substrate DNA[137]

### DNA-modifying enzymes

#### Nucleases and ligases

[Nucleases](/wiki/Nuclease "Nuclease") are [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme")
that cut DNA strands by catalyzing the [hydrolysis](/wiki/Hydrolysis
"Hydrolysis") of the [phosphodiester bonds](/wiki/Phosphodiester_bond
"Phosphodiester bond"). Nucleases that hydrolyse nucleotides from the ends of
DNA strands are called [exonucleases](/wiki/Exonuclease "Exonuclease"), while
[endonucleases](/wiki/Endonuclease "Endonuclease") cut within strands. The
most frequently used nucleases in [molecular biology](/wiki/Molecular_biology
"Molecular biology") are the [restriction
endonucleases](/wiki/Restriction_enzyme "Restriction enzyme"), which cut DNA
at specific sequences. For instance, the EcoRV enzyme shown to the left
recognizes the 6-base sequence 5′-GATATC-3′ and makes a cut at the horizontal
line. In nature, these enzymes protect [bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria "Bacteria")
against [phage](/wiki/Bacteriophage "Bacteriophage") infection by digesting
the phage DNA when it enters the bacterial cell, acting as part of the
[restriction modification system](/wiki/Restriction_modification_system
"Restriction modification system").[138] In technology, these sequence-
specific nucleases are used in [molecular cloning](/wiki/Molecular_cloning
"Molecular cloning") and [DNA fingerprinting](/wiki/Genetic_fingerprinting
"Genetic fingerprinting").

Enzymes called [DNA ligases](/wiki/DNA_ligase "DNA ligase") can rejoin cut or
broken DNA strands.[139] Ligases are particularly important in [lagging
strand](/wiki/Replication_fork "Replication fork") DNA replication, as they
join together the short segments of DNA produced at the [replication
fork](/wiki/Replication_fork "Replication fork") into a complete copy of the
DNA template. They are also used in [DNA repair](/wiki/DNA_repair "DNA
repair") and [genetic recombination](/wiki/Genetic_recombination "Genetic
recombination").[139]

#### Topoisomerases and helicases

[Topoisomerases](/wiki/Topoisomerase "Topoisomerase") are enzymes with both
nuclease and ligase activity. These proteins change the amount of
[supercoiling](/wiki/DNA_supercoil "DNA supercoil") in DNA. Some of these
enzymes work by cutting the DNA helix and allowing one section to rotate,
thereby reducing its level of supercoiling; the enzyme then seals the DNA
break.[60] Other types of these enzymes are capable of cutting one DNA helix
and then passing a second strand of DNA through this break, before rejoining
the helix.[140] Topoisomerases are required for many processes involving DNA,
such as DNA replication and transcription.[61]

[Helicases](/wiki/Helicase "Helicase") are proteins that are a type of
[molecular motor](/wiki/Molecular_motor "Molecular motor"). They use the
chemical energy in [nucleoside triphosphates](/wiki/Nucleoside_triphosphate
"Nucleoside triphosphate"), predominantly [adenosine
triphosphate](/wiki/Adenosine_triphosphate "Adenosine triphosphate") (ATP), to
break hydrogen bonds between bases and unwind the DNA double helix into single
strands.[141] These enzymes are essential for most processes where enzymes
need to access the DNA bases.

#### Polymerases

[Polymerases](/wiki/Polymerase "Polymerase") are [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme
"Enzyme") that synthesize polynucleotide chains from [nucleoside
triphosphates](/wiki/Nucleoside_triphosphate "Nucleoside triphosphate"). The
sequence of their products is created based on existing polynucleotide
chains—which are called _templates_. These enzymes function by repeatedly
adding a nucleotide to the 3′ [hydroxyl](/wiki/Hydroxyl "Hydroxyl") group at
the end of the growing polynucleotide chain. As a consequence, all polymerases
work in a 5′ to 3′ direction.[142] In the [active site](/wiki/Active_site
"Active site") of these enzymes, the incoming nucleoside triphosphate base-
pairs to the template: this allows polymerases to accurately synthesize the
complementary strand of their template. Polymerases are classified according
to the type of template that they use.

In DNA replication, DNA-dependent [DNA polymerases](/wiki/DNA_polymerase "DNA
polymerase") make copies of DNA polynucleotide chains. To preserve biological
information, it is essential that the sequence of bases in each copy are
precisely complementary to the sequence of bases in the template strand. Many
DNA polymerases have a [proofreading](/wiki/Proofreading_\(biology\)
"Proofreading \(biology\)") activity. Here, the polymerase recognizes the
occasional mistakes in the synthesis reaction by the lack of base pairing
between the mismatched nucleotides. If a mismatch is detected, a 3′ to 5′
[exonuclease](/wiki/Exonuclease "Exonuclease") activity is activated and the
incorrect base removed.[143] In most organisms, DNA polymerases function in a
large complex called the [replisome](/wiki/Replisome "Replisome") that
contains multiple accessory subunits, such as the [DNA clamp](/wiki/DNA_clamp
"DNA clamp") or [helicases](/wiki/Helicase "Helicase").[144]

RNA-dependent DNA polymerases are a specialized class of polymerases that copy
the sequence of an RNA strand into DNA. They include [reverse
transcriptase](/wiki/Reverse_transcriptase "Reverse transcriptase"), which is
a [viral](/wiki/Virus "Virus") enzyme involved in the infection of cells by
[retroviruses](/wiki/Retrovirus "Retrovirus"), and
[telomerase](/wiki/Telomerase "Telomerase"), which is required for the
replication of telomeres.[78][145] For example, HIV reverse transcriptase is
an enzyme for AIDS virus replication.[145] Telomerase is an unusual polymerase
because it contains its own RNA template as part of its structure. It
synthesizes [telomeres](/wiki/Telomeres "Telomeres") at the ends of
chromosomes. Telomeres prevent fusion of the ends of neighboring chromosomes
and protect chromosome ends from damage.[79]

Transcription is carried out by a DNA-dependent [RNA
polymerase](/wiki/RNA_polymerase "RNA polymerase") that copies the sequence of
a DNA strand into RNA. To begin transcribing a gene, the RNA polymerase binds
to a sequence of DNA called a promoter and separates the DNA strands. It then
copies the gene sequence into a [messenger RNA](/wiki/Messenger_RNA "Messenger
RNA") transcript until it reaches a region of DNA called the
[terminator](/wiki/Terminator_\(genetics\) "Terminator \(genetics\)"), where
it halts and detaches from the DNA. As with human DNA-dependent DNA
polymerases, [RNA polymerase II](/wiki/RNA_polymerase_II "RNA polymerase II"),
the enzyme that transcribes most of the genes in the human genome, operates as
part of a large [protein complex](/wiki/Protein_complex "Protein complex")
with multiple regulatory and accessory subunits.[146]

## Genetic recombination

[![Holliday
Junction.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Holliday_Junction.svg/250px-
Holliday_Junction.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Holliday_Junction.svg)  
---  
[![Holliday junction
coloured.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Holliday_junction_coloured.png/250px-
Holliday_junction_coloured.png)](/wiki/File:Holliday_junction_coloured.png)  
  
Structure of the [Holliday junction](/wiki/Holliday_junction "Holliday
junction") intermediate in [genetic recombination](/wiki/Genetic_recombination
"Genetic recombination"). The four separate DNA strands are coloured red,
blue, green and yellow.[147]

Further information: [Genetic recombination](/wiki/Genetic_recombination
"Genetic recombination")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Chromosomal_Recombination.svg/250px-
Chromosomal_Recombination.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Chromosomal_Recombination.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Chromosomal_Recombination.svg "Enlarge")

Recombination involves the breaking and rejoining of two chromosomes (M and F)
to produce two rearranged chromosomes (C1 and C2).

A DNA helix usually does not interact with other segments of DNA, and in human
cells, the different chromosomes even occupy separate areas in the nucleus
called "[chromosome territories](/wiki/Chromosome_territories "Chromosome
territories")".[148] This physical separation of different chromosomes is
important for the ability of DNA to function as a stable repository for
information, as one of the few times chromosomes interact is in [chromosomal
crossover](/wiki/Chromosomal_crossover "Chromosomal crossover") which occurs
during [sexual reproduction](/wiki/Sexual_reproduction "Sexual reproduction"),
when [genetic recombination](/wiki/Genetic_recombination "Genetic
recombination") occurs. Chromosomal crossover is when two DNA helices break,
swap a section and then rejoin.

Recombination allows chromosomes to exchange genetic information and produces
new combinations of genes, which increases the efficiency of [natural
selection](/wiki/Natural_selection "Natural selection") and can be important
in the rapid evolution of new proteins.[149] Genetic recombination can also be
involved in DNA repair, particularly in the cell's response to double-strand
breaks.[150]

The most common form of chromosomal crossover is [homologous
recombination](/wiki/Homologous_recombination "Homologous recombination"),
where the two chromosomes involved share very similar sequences. Non-
homologous recombination can be damaging to cells, as it can produce
[chromosomal translocations](/wiki/Chromosomal_translocation "Chromosomal
translocation") and genetic abnormalities. The recombination reaction is
catalyzed by enzymes known as [recombinases](/wiki/Recombinase "Recombinase"),
such as [RAD51](/wiki/RAD51 "RAD51").[151] The first step in recombination is
a double-stranded break caused by either an [endonuclease](/wiki/Endonuclease
"Endonuclease") or damage to the DNA.[152] A series of steps catalyzed in part
by the recombinase then leads to joining of the two helices by at least one
[Holliday junction](/wiki/Holliday_junction "Holliday junction"), in which a
segment of a single strand in each helix is annealed to the complementary
strand in the other helix. The Holliday junction is a tetrahedral junction
structure that can be moved along the pair of chromosomes, swapping one strand
for another. The recombination reaction is then halted by cleavage of the
junction and re-ligation of the released DNA.[153] Only strands of like
polarity exchange DNA during recombination. There are two types of cleavage:
east-west cleavage and north-south cleavage. The north-south cleavage nicks
both strands of DNA, while the east-west cleavage has one strand of DNA
intact. The formation of a Holliday junction during recombination makes it
possible for genetic diversity, genes to exchange on chromosomes, and
expression of wild-type viral genomes.

## Evolution

Further information: [RNA world hypothesis](/wiki/RNA_world_hypothesis "RNA
world hypothesis")

DNA contains the genetic information that allows all modern living things to
function, grow and reproduce. However, it is unclear how long in the
4-billion-year [history of life](/wiki/Timeline_of_evolution "Timeline of
evolution") DNA has performed this function, as it has been proposed that the
earliest forms of life may have used RNA as their genetic material.[154][155]
RNA may have acted as the central part of early [cell
metabolism](/wiki/Cell_metabolism "Cell metabolism") as it can both transmit
genetic information and carry out [catalysis](/wiki/Catalysis "Catalysis") as
part of [ribozymes](/wiki/Ribozyme "Ribozyme").[156] This ancient [RNA
world](/wiki/RNA_world_hypothesis "RNA world hypothesis") where nucleic acid
would have been used for both catalysis and genetics may have influenced the
[evolution](/wiki/Evolution "Evolution") of the current genetic code based on
four nucleotide bases. This would occur, since the number of different bases
in such an organism is a trade-off between a small number of bases increasing
replication accuracy and a large number of bases increasing the catalytic
efficiency of ribozymes.[157] However, there is no direct evidence of ancient
genetic systems, as recovery of DNA from most fossils is impossible because
DNA survives in the environment for less than one million years, and slowly
degrades into short fragments in solution.[158] Claims for older DNA have been
made, most notably a report of the isolation of a viable bacterium from a salt
crystal 250 million years old,[159] but these claims are
controversial.[160][161]

Building blocks of DNA ([adenine](/wiki/Adenine "Adenine"),
[guanine](/wiki/Guanine "Guanine"), and related [organic
molecules](/wiki/Organic_molecules "Organic molecules")) may have been formed
extraterrestrially in [outer space](/wiki/Outer_space "Outer
space").[162][163][164] Complex DNA and [RNA](/wiki/RNA "RNA") [organic
compounds](/wiki/Organic_compound "Organic compound") of [life](/wiki/Life
"Life"), including [uracil](/wiki/Uracil "Uracil"), [cytosine](/wiki/Cytosine
"Cytosine"), and [thymine](/wiki/Thymine "Thymine"), have also been formed in
the laboratory under conditions mimicking those found in [outer
space](/wiki/Outer_space "Outer space"), using starting chemicals, such as
[pyrimidine](/wiki/Pyrimidine "Pyrimidine"), found in
[meteorites](/wiki/Meteorite "Meteorite"). Pyrimidine, like [polycyclic
aromatic hydrocarbons](/wiki/Polycyclic_aromatic_hydrocarbons "Polycyclic
aromatic hydrocarbons") (PAHs), the most carbon-rich chemical found in the
[universe](/wiki/Universe "Universe"), may have been formed in [red
giants](/wiki/Red_giant "Red giant") or in interstellar [cosmic
dust](/wiki/Cosmic_dust "Cosmic dust") and gas clouds.[165]

## Uses in technology

### Genetic engineering

Further information: [Molecular biology](/wiki/Molecular_biology "Molecular
biology"), [Nucleic acid methods](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_methods "Nucleic acid
methods"), and [Genetic engineering](/wiki/Genetic_engineering "Genetic
engineering")

Methods have been developed to purify DNA from organisms, such as [phenol-
chloroform extraction](/wiki/Phenol-chloroform_extraction "Phenol-chloroform
extraction"), and to manipulate it in the laboratory, such as [restriction
digests](/wiki/Restriction_digest "Restriction digest") and the [polymerase
chain reaction](/wiki/Polymerase_chain_reaction "Polymerase chain reaction").
Modern [biology](/wiki/Biology "Biology") and
[biochemistry](/wiki/Biochemistry "Biochemistry") make intensive use of these
techniques in recombinant DNA technology. [Recombinant
DNA](/wiki/Recombinant_DNA "Recombinant DNA") is a man-made DNA sequence that
has been assembled from other DNA sequences. They can be
[transformed](/wiki/Transformation_\(genetics\) "Transformation \(genetics\)")
into organisms in the form of [plasmids](/wiki/Plasmid "Plasmid") or in the
appropriate format, by using a [viral vector](/wiki/Viral_vector "Viral
vector").[166] The [genetically modified](/wiki/Genetic_engineering "Genetic
engineering") organisms produced can be used to produce products such as
recombinant [proteins](/wiki/Protein "Protein"), used in [medical
research](/wiki/Medical_research "Medical research"),[167] or be grown in
[agriculture](/wiki/Agriculture "Agriculture").[168][169]

### DNA profiling

Further information: [DNA profiling](/wiki/DNA_profiling "DNA profiling")

[Forensic scientists](/wiki/Forensic_science "Forensic science") can use DNA
in [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood"), [semen](/wiki/Semen "Semen"),
[skin](/wiki/Skin "Skin"), [saliva](/wiki/Saliva "Saliva") or
[hair](/wiki/Hair "Hair") found at a [crime scene](/wiki/Crime_scene "Crime
scene") to identify a matching DNA of an individual, such as a
perpetrator.[170] This process is formally termed [DNA
profiling](/wiki/DNA_profiling "DNA profiling"), but may also be called
"[genetic fingerprinting](/wiki/Genetic_fingerprinting "Genetic
fingerprinting")". In DNA profiling, the lengths of variable sections of
repetitive DNA, such as [short tandem repeats](/wiki/Short_tandem_repeat
"Short tandem repeat") and [minisatellites](/wiki/Minisatellite
"Minisatellite"), are compared between people. This method is usually an
extremely reliable technique for identifying a matching DNA.[171] However,
identification can be complicated if the scene is contaminated with DNA from
several people.[172] DNA profiling was developed in 1984 by British geneticist
Sir [Alec Jeffreys](/wiki/Alec_Jeffreys "Alec Jeffreys"),[173] and first used
in forensic science to convict Colin Pitchfork in the 1988 [Enderby
murders](/wiki/Colin_Pitchfork "Colin Pitchfork") case.[174]

The development of forensic science and the ability to now obtain genetic
matching on minute samples of blood, skin, saliva, or hair has led to re-
examining many cases. Evidence can now be uncovered that was scientifically
impossible at the time of the original examination. Combined with the removal
of the [double jeopardy](/wiki/Double_jeopardy "Double jeopardy") law in some
places, this can allow cases to be reopened where prior trials have failed to
produce sufficient evidence to convince a jury. People charged with serious
crimes may be required to provide a sample of DNA for matching purposes. The
most obvious defense to DNA matches obtained forensically is to claim that
cross-contamination of evidence has occurred. This has resulted in meticulous
strict handling procedures with new cases of serious crime. DNA profiling is
also used successfully to positively identify victims of mass casualty
incidents,[175] bodies or body parts in serious accidents, and individual
victims in mass war graves, via matching to family members.

DNA profiling is also used in [DNA paternity
testing](/wiki/DNA_paternity_testing "DNA paternity testing") to determine if
someone is the biological parent or grandparent of a child with the
probability of parentage is typically 99.99% when the alleged parent is
biologically related to the child. Normal [DNA
sequencing](/wiki/DNA_sequencing "DNA sequencing") methods happen after birth,
but there are new methods to test paternity while a mother is still
pregnant.[176]

### DNA enzymes or catalytic DNA

Further information: [Deoxyribozyme](/wiki/Deoxyribozyme "Deoxyribozyme")

[Deoxyribozymes](/wiki/Deoxyribozyme "Deoxyribozyme"), also called DNAzymes or
catalytic DNA, are first discovered in 1994.[177] They are mostly single
stranded DNA sequences isolated from a large pool of random DNA sequences
through a combinatorial approach called [in vitro](/wiki/In_vitro "In vitro")
selection or [systematic evolution of ligands by exponential
enrichment](/wiki/Systematic_evolution_of_ligands_by_exponential_enrichment
"Systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment") (SELEX). DNAzymes
catalyze variety of chemical reactions including RNA-DNA cleavage, RNA-DNA
ligation, amino acids phosphorylation-dephosphorylation, carbon-carbon bond
formation, and etc. DNAzymes can enhance catalytic rate of chemical reactions
up to 100,000,000,000-fold over the uncatalyzed reaction.[178] The most
extensively studied class of DNAzymes is RNA-cleaving types which have been
used to detect different metal ions and designing therapeutic agents. Several
metal-specific DNAzymes have been reported including the GR-5 DNAzyme (lead-
specific),[177] the CA1-3 DNAzymes (copper-specific),[179] the 39E DNAzyme
(uranyl-specific) and the NaA43 DNAzyme (sodium-specific).[180] The NaA43
DNAzyme, which is reported to be more than 10,000-fold selective for sodium
over other metal ions, was used to make a real-time sodium sensor in living
cells.

### Bioinformatics

Further information: [Bioinformatics](/wiki/Bioinformatics "Bioinformatics")

[Bioinformatics](/wiki/Bioinformatics "Bioinformatics") involves the
development of techniques to store, [data mine](/wiki/Data_mining "Data
mining"), search and manipulate biological data, including DNA [nucleic acid
sequence](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_sequence "Nucleic acid sequence") data. These
have led to widely applied advances in [computer
science](/wiki/Computer_science "Computer science"), especially [string
searching algorithms](/wiki/String_searching_algorithm "String searching
algorithm"), [machine learning](/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning"),
and [database theory](/wiki/Database_theory "Database theory").[181] String
searching or matching algorithms, which find an occurrence of a sequence of
letters inside a larger sequence of letters, were developed to search for
specific sequences of nucleotides.[182] The DNA sequence may be
[aligned](/wiki/Sequence_alignment "Sequence alignment") with other DNA
sequences to identify [homologous](/wiki/Homology_\(biology\) "Homology
\(biology\)") sequences and locate the specific [mutations](/wiki/Mutation
"Mutation") that make them distinct. These techniques, especially [multiple
sequence alignment](/wiki/Multiple_sequence_alignment "Multiple sequence
alignment"), are used in studying [phylogenetic](/wiki/Phylogenetics
"Phylogenetics") relationships and protein function.[183] Data sets
representing entire genomes' worth of DNA sequences, such as those produced by
the [Human Genome Project](/wiki/Human_Genome_Project "Human Genome Project"),
are difficult to use without the annotations that identify the locations of
genes and regulatory elements on each chromosome. Regions of DNA sequence that
have the characteristic patterns associated with protein- or RNA-coding genes
can be identified by [gene finding](/wiki/Gene_prediction "Gene prediction")
algorithms, which allow researchers to predict the presence of particular
[gene products](/wiki/Gene_product "Gene product") and their possible
functions in an organism even before they have been isolated
experimentally.[184] Entire genomes may also be compared, which can shed light
on the evolutionary history of particular organism and permit the examination
of complex evolutionary events.

### DNA nanotechnology

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/DNA_nanostructures.png/400px-
DNA_nanostructures.png)](/wiki/File:DNA_nanostructures.png)

[](/wiki/File:DNA_nanostructures.png "Enlarge")

The DNA structure at left (schematic shown) will self-assemble into the
structure visualized by [atomic force
microscopy](/wiki/Atomic_force_microscope "Atomic force microscope") at right.
[DNA nanotechnology](/wiki/DNA_nanotechnology "DNA nanotechnology") is the
field that seeks to design nanoscale structures using the [molecular
recognition](/wiki/Molecular_recognition "Molecular recognition") properties
of DNA molecules. Image from [Strong,
2004](https://doi.org/10.1371%2Fjournal.pbio.0020073).

Further information: [DNA nanotechnology](/wiki/DNA_nanotechnology "DNA
nanotechnology")

DNA nanotechnology uses the unique [molecular
recognition](/wiki/Molecular_recognition "Molecular recognition") properties
of DNA and other nucleic acids to create self-assembling branched DNA
complexes with useful properties.[185] DNA is thus used as a structural
material rather than as a carrier of biological information. This has led to
the creation of two-dimensional periodic lattices (both tile-based and using
the _[DNA origami](/wiki/DNA_origami "DNA origami")_ method) and three-
dimensional structures in the shapes of [polyhedra](/wiki/Polyhedron
"Polyhedron").[186] [Nanomechanical devices](/wiki/DNA_machine "DNA machine")
and [algorithmic self-assembly](/wiki/DNA_computing "DNA computing") have also
been demonstrated,[187] and these DNA structures have been used to template
the arrangement of other molecules such as [gold
nanoparticles](/wiki/Colloidal_gold "Colloidal gold") and
[streptavidin](/wiki/Streptavidin "Streptavidin") proteins.[188]

### History and anthropology

Further information: [Phylogenetics](/wiki/Phylogenetics "Phylogenetics") and
[Genetic genealogy](/wiki/Genetic_genealogy "Genetic genealogy")

Because DNA collects mutations over time, which are then inherited, it
contains historical information, and, by comparing DNA sequences, geneticists
can infer the evolutionary history of organisms, their
[phylogeny](/wiki/Phylogenetics "Phylogenetics").[189] This field of
phylogenetics is a powerful tool in [evolutionary
biology](/wiki/Evolutionary_biology "Evolutionary biology"). If DNA sequences
within a species are compared, [population
geneticists](/wiki/Population_genetics "Population genetics") can learn the
history of particular populations. This can be used in studies ranging from
[ecological genetics](/wiki/Ecological_genetics "Ecological genetics") to
[anthropology](/wiki/Anthropology "Anthropology").

### Information storage

Main article: [DNA digital data storage](/wiki/DNA_digital_data_storage "DNA
digital data storage")

In a paper published in _[Nature](/wiki/Nature_\(journal\) "Nature
\(journal\)")_ in January 2013, scientists from the [European Bioinformatics
Institute](/wiki/European_Bioinformatics_Institute "European Bioinformatics
Institute") and [Agilent Technologies](/wiki/Agilent_Technologies "Agilent
Technologies") proposed a mechanism to use DNA's ability to code information
as a means of digital data storage. The group was able to encode 739 kilobytes
of data into DNA code, synthesize the actual DNA, then sequence the DNA and
decode the information back to its original form, with a reported 100%
accuracy. The encoded information consisted of text files and audio files. A
prior experiment was published in August 2012. It was conducted by researchers
at [Harvard University](/wiki/Harvard_University "Harvard University"), where
the text of a 54,000-word book was encoded in DNA.[190][191]

Moreover, in living cells, the storage can be turned active by enzymes. Light-
gated protein domains fused to DNA processing enzymes are suitable for that
task _in vitro_.[192][193] Fluorescent exonucleases can transmit the output
according to the nucleotide they have read.[194]

## History

Further information: [History of molecular
biology](/wiki/History_of_molecular_biology "History of molecular biology")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Maclyn_McCarty_with_Francis_Crick_and_James_D_Watson_-_10.1371_journal.pbio.0030341.g001-O.jpg/220px-
Maclyn_McCarty_with_Francis_Crick_and_James_D_Watson_-_10.1371_journal.pbio.0030341.g001-O.jpg)](/wiki/File:Maclyn_McCarty_with_Francis_Crick_and_James_D_Watson_-_10.1371_journal.pbio.0030341.g001-O.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Maclyn_McCarty_with_Francis_Crick_and_James_D_Watson_-_10.1371_journal.pbio.0030341.g001-O.jpg
"Enlarge")

[James Watson](/wiki/James_Watson "James Watson") and [Francis
Crick](/wiki/Francis_Crick "Francis Crick") (right), co-originators of the
double-helix model, with Maclyn McCarty (left)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Pencil_sketch_of_the_DNA_double_helix_by_Francis_Crick_Wellcome_L0051225.jpg/220px-
Pencil_sketch_of_the_DNA_double_helix_by_Francis_Crick_Wellcome_L0051225.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pencil_sketch_of_the_DNA_double_helix_by_Francis_Crick_Wellcome_L0051225.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pencil_sketch_of_the_DNA_double_helix_by_Francis_Crick_Wellcome_L0051225.jpg
"Enlarge")

Pencil sketch of the DNA double helix by Francis Crick in 1953

DNA was first isolated by the Swiss physician [Friedrich
Miescher](/wiki/Friedrich_Miescher "Friedrich Miescher") who, in 1869,
discovered a microscopic substance in the pus of discarded surgical bandages.
As it resided in the nuclei of cells, he called it "nuclein".[195][196] In
1878, [Albrecht Kossel](/wiki/Albrecht_Kossel "Albrecht Kossel") isolated the
non-protein component of "nuclein", nucleic acid, and later isolated its five
primary [nucleobases](/wiki/Nucleobase "Nucleobase").[197][198]

In 1909, [Phoebus Levene](/wiki/Phoebus_Levene "Phoebus Levene") identified
the base, sugar, and phosphate nucleotide unit of the RNA (then named "yeast
nucleic acid").[199][200][201] In 1929, Levene identified deoxyribose sugar in
"thymus nucleic acid" (DNA).[202] Levene suggested that DNA consisted of a
string of four nucleotide units linked together through the phosphate groups
("tetranucleotide hypothesis"). Levene thought the chain was short and the
bases repeated in a fixed order. In 1927, [Nikolai
Koltsov](/wiki/Nikolai_Koltsov "Nikolai Koltsov") proposed that inherited
traits would be inherited via a "giant hereditary molecule" made up of "two
mirror strands that would replicate in a semi-conservative fashion using each
strand as a template".[203][204] In 1928, [Frederick
Griffith](/wiki/Frederick_Griffith "Frederick Griffith") in his
[experiment](/wiki/Griffith%27s_experiment "Griffith's experiment") discovered
that [traits](/wiki/Trait_\(biology\) "Trait \(biology\)") of the "smooth"
form of _Pneumococcus_ could be transferred to the "rough" form of the same
bacteria by mixing killed "smooth" bacteria with the live "rough"
form.[205][206] This system provided the first clear suggestion that DNA
carries genetic information.

In 1933, while studying virgin [sea urchin](/wiki/Sea_urchin "Sea urchin")
eggs, [Jean Brachet](/wiki/Jean_Brachet "Jean Brachet") suggested that DNA is
found in [cell nucleus](/wiki/Cell_nucleus "Cell nucleus") and that
[RNA](/wiki/RNA "RNA") is present exclusively in the
[cytoplasm](/wiki/Cytoplasm "Cytoplasm"). At the time, "yeast nucleic acid"
(RNA) was thought to occur only in plants, while "thymus nucleic acid" (DNA)
only in animals. The latter was thought to be a tetramer, with the function of
buffering cellular pH.[207][208]

In 1937, [William Astbury](/wiki/William_Astbury "William Astbury") produced
the first X-ray diffraction patterns that showed that DNA had a regular
structure.[209]

In 1943, [Oswald Avery](/wiki/Oswald_Avery "Oswald Avery"), along with
coworkers [Colin MacLeod](/wiki/Colin_Munro_MacLeod "Colin Munro MacLeod") and
[Maclyn McCarty](/wiki/Maclyn_McCarty "Maclyn McCarty"), identified DNA as the
[transforming principle](/wiki/Griffith%27s_experiment "Griffith's
experiment"), supporting Griffith's suggestion ([Avery–MacLeod–McCarty
experiment](/wiki/Avery%E2%80%93MacLeod%E2%80%93McCarty_experiment
"Avery–MacLeod–McCarty experiment")).[210] DNA's role in
[heredity](/wiki/Heredity "Heredity") was confirmed in 1952 when [Alfred
Hershey](/wiki/Alfred_Hershey "Alfred Hershey") and [Martha
Chase](/wiki/Martha_Chase "Martha Chase") in the [Hershey–Chase
experiment](/wiki/Hershey%E2%80%93Chase_experiment "Hershey–Chase experiment")
showed that DNA is the [genetic material](/wiki/Genetic_material "Genetic
material") of the [T2 phage](/wiki/Enterobacteria_phage_T2 "Enterobacteria
phage T2").[211]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/TheEaglePub-
Cambridge-BluePlaque.jpg/220px-TheEaglePub-Cambridge-
BluePlaque.jpg)](/wiki/File:TheEaglePub-Cambridge-BluePlaque.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TheEaglePub-Cambridge-BluePlaque.jpg "Enlarge")

A [blue plaque](/wiki/Blue_plaque "Blue plaque") outside [The
Eagle](/wiki/The_Eagle,_Cambridge "The Eagle, Cambridge") [pub](/wiki/Pub
"Pub") commemorating Crick and Watson

Late in 1951, [Francis Crick](/wiki/Francis_Crick "Francis Crick") started
working with [James Watson](/wiki/James_Watson "James Watson") at the
[Cavendish Laboratory](/wiki/Cavendish_Laboratory "Cavendish Laboratory")
within the [University of Cambridge](/wiki/University_of_Cambridge "University
of Cambridge"). In 1953, Watson and Crick suggested what is now accepted as
the first correct double-helix model of [DNA
structure](/wiki/Molecular_structure_of_Nucleic_Acids "Molecular structure of
Nucleic Acids") in the journal _Nature_.[9] Their double-helix, molecular
model of DNA was then based on one [X-ray diffraction](/wiki/X-ray_diffraction
"X-ray diffraction") image (labeled as "[Photo 51](/wiki/Photo_51 "Photo
51")")[212] taken by [Rosalind Franklin](/wiki/Rosalind_Franklin "Rosalind
Franklin") and [Raymond Gosling](/wiki/Raymond_Gosling "Raymond Gosling") in
May 1952, and the information that the DNA bases are paired. On 28 February
1953 Crick interrupted patrons' lunchtime at [The
Eagle](/wiki/The_Eagle,_Cambridge "The Eagle, Cambridge") [pub](/wiki/Pub
"Pub") in Cambridge to announce that he and Watson had "discovered the secret
of life".[213]

Months earlier, in February 1953, [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling "Linus
Pauling") and [Robert Corey](/wiki/Robert_Corey "Robert Corey") proposed a
model for nucleic acids containing three intertwined chains, with the
phosphates near the axis, and the bases on the outside.[214] Experimental
evidence supporting the Watson and Crick model was published in a series of
five articles in the same issue of _Nature_.[215] Of these, Franklin and
Gosling's paper was the first publication of their own X-ray diffraction data
and original analysis method that partly supported the Watson and Crick
model;[64][216] this issue also contained an article on DNA structure by
[Maurice Wilkins](/wiki/Maurice_Wilkins "Maurice Wilkins") and two of his
colleagues, whose analysis and _in vivo_ B-DNA X-ray patterns also supported
the presence _in vivo_ of the double-helical DNA configurations as proposed by
Crick and Watson for their double-helix molecular model of DNA in the prior
two pages of _Nature_.[65] In 1962, after Franklin's death, Watson, Crick, and
Wilkins jointly received the [Nobel Prize in Physiology or
Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine "Nobel Prize in
Physiology or Medicine").[217] Nobel Prizes are awarded only to living
recipients. A debate continues about who should receive credit for the
discovery.[218]

In an influential presentation in 1957, Crick laid out the [central dogma of
molecular biology](/wiki/Central_dogma_of_molecular_biology "Central dogma of
molecular biology"), which foretold the relationship between DNA, RNA, and
proteins, and articulated the "adaptor hypothesis".[219] Final confirmation of
the replication mechanism that was implied by the double-helical structure
followed in 1958 through the [Meselson–Stahl
experiment](/wiki/Meselson%E2%80%93Stahl_experiment "Meselson–Stahl
experiment").[220] Further work by Crick and coworkers showed that the genetic
code was based on non-overlapping triplets of bases, called codons, allowing
[Har Gobind Khorana](/wiki/Har_Gobind_Khorana "Har Gobind Khorana"), [Robert
W. Holley](/wiki/Robert_W._Holley "Robert W. Holley"), and [Marshall Warren
Nirenberg](/wiki/Marshall_Warren_Nirenberg "Marshall Warren Nirenberg") to
decipher the genetic code.[221] These findings represent the birth of
molecular biology.[222]

  * [Genetic Education Modules for Teachers](http://www.genome.gov/10506718)— _DNA from the Beginning_ Study Guide
  * [PDB](/wiki/Protein_Data_Bank "Protein Data Bank") Molecule of the Month _[DNA](https://pdb101.rcsb.org/motm/23)_
  * [Clue to chemistry of heredity found](https://www.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/science/dna-article.pdf) [The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times") June 1953. First American newspaper coverage of the discovery of the DNA structure
  * [Olby R](/wiki/Robert_Olby "Robert Olby") (January 2003). "Quiet debut for the double helix". _Nature_. **421** (6921): 402–5. [Bibcode](/wiki/Bibcode "Bibcode"):[2003Natur.421..402O](http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003Natur.421..402O). [doi](/wiki/Digital_object_identifier "Digital object identifier"):[10.1038/nature01397](//doi.org/10.1038%2Fnature01397). [PMID](/wiki/PubMed_Identifier "PubMed Identifier") [12540907](//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12540907).
  * [DNA from the Beginning](http://www.dnaftb.org/) Another DNA Learning Center site on DNA, genes, and heredity from Mendel to the human genome project.
  * [The Register of Francis Crick Personal Papers 1938 – 2007](https://web.archive.org/web/20070825101712/http://orpheus.ucsd.edu/speccoll/testing/html/mss0660a.html#abstract) at Mandeville Special Collections Library, [University of California, San Diego](/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Diego "University of California, San Diego")
  * [Seven-page, handwritten letter that Crick sent to his 12-year-old son Michael in 1953 describing the structure of DNA.](http://www.nature.com/polopoly_fs/7.9746!/file/Crick%20letter%20to%20Michael.pdf) See [Crick’s medal goes under the hammer](http://www.nature.com/news/crick-s-medal-goes-under-the-hammer-1.12705), Nature, 5 April 2013.
